awd_titl_txt: NRT-IGE: Research to Innovation to Society
awd_abstract_narration:
The world's innovation landscape is changing. Innovation has become a fundamental prerequisite for sustainability that embraces not only the discovery of new ideas but also implementable research solutions to societal and market requirements. Addressing this shift requires STEM professionals who are simultaneously excellent researchers, capable innovators, and skilled leaders. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award in the Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) Track to Oregon State University will pilot and test a team-based, experiential curriculum that simultaneously integrates basic scientific research with market research and with professional skill development and practice. Learning outcome and evaluation data will be used to determine if this transformative curriculum develops researchers with the desired attributes to contribute to the national STEM agenda.  If successful, the pilot will lay the foundation for institutionalization of this team-based, experiential approach as a new graduate STEM degree option that can be adopted at universities across the nation. 

The Research to Innovation to Society educational platform is built upon the Lens of the Market program and aims to train STEM graduate students across all disciplines as career resilient, innovative scientists and engineers.  Academic and industrial scientists and engineers with demonstrated track records of STEM commercial and leadership success will partner with educational faculty to implement the curriculum.  Two cohorts of interdisciplinary graduate student teams, supported by their faculty advisors, will expand their disciplinary research to explore implementable research solutions to societal and market requirements through an experiential learning process. Instruction will be delivered through multiple formats including face-to-face team interactions in a traditional classroom setting and online through videos, webinars and assignments; all materials are designed to be scalable and broadly accessible online.  To support their project, teams will gather data from both primary and secondary sources, exposing them to experts in both business and academe. The curriculum is designed to develop networking, communication, data gathering and business analytic skills, as well as provide a broader societal context for the students' disciplinary research. Monthly presentations of findings by teams will culminate in a capstone presentation to faculty, administration, market leaders and innovation ecosystem leaders both online and face-to-face. Assessment and evaluation at multiple stages of the students' work by peers, instructors and market/business experts will form the basis for recommending adoption of this approach as a transformative alternative STEM graduate degree. 

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new, potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The Innovations in Graduate Education Track is dedicated solely to piloting, testing, and evaluating novel, innovative, and potentially transformative approaches to graduate education.

por.por_cntn:
This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award entitled “Research to Innovation to Society” to Oregon State University in the Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) Track piloted and tested a team-based, experiential curriculum that integrated basic scientific and market research with professional skill development and practice. 

 

OUTCOMES:

1. The project produced multiple broader impacts: graduates with the skills needed to align basic scientific research with societal needs along any career path, market information to influence ongoing and proposed basic scientific research projects, expanded faculty engagement in the innovation process, and validated data to support next steps in commercializing a product of scientific research.

 

2. The project created a three-course, academic-year sequence based on the Lens of the Market® program. An instructor of record and facilitators with industrial experience guide up to five teams, each comprising up to five students, through the course material. Each term culminates with the teams presenting their findings in a public presentation to an audience comprising peers, University faculty, and industry leaders. The instructor evaluates all work - supported by student examination of team and individual performance.

 

Foundations of Innovation. Students learn the basic language and initial skill set needed to address how scientific ideas and research results become innovations – solutions that address societal and market needs. Student teams work in areas aligned with their scientific interests. Platform diagrams, generated in collaboration with faculty researchers, guide each team in selection of their market-application pair for analysis. Students develop their analyses throughout the entire course sequence based on this pair. Teams build a value proposition and value chains, create a competitive score card, while integrating concepts of sustainable value in all their work. 

 

Research to Innovation. This course builds on the skills acquired in Foundations of Innovation. Students learn effective ways to collect market data from primary and secondary sources and to assess its completeness. They gain and improve skills to interview technical and market experts. They are guided through the process by aligning multiple risk-reward questions to specific locations in their value chains. As data are collected, each team also continuously reflects on and updates their value proposition and gap analysis. 

 

Innovation to Impact. This course builds on the skills acquired in Foundations of Innovation and the data collected in Research to Innovation.  Teams review and determine whether the data collected from the validated and value-chain aligned data sources are sufficient to summarize results for each question. They then build valid grounded assumptions for each question based on the data summaries and employ them in a Star Market analysis to characterize and chart the potential for an offering in the selected market. Students summarize their work in a final public presentation, which includes all the learnings and findings from the entire course sequence.

 

 

3. Lens of the Market® developer, ecosVC teamed with OSU’s PACE continuing education organization and an offering is available online for all. Lensof the market Researc2Innovation is a four module self-paced course that can be used independently or in conjunction with a course format. https://workspace.oregonstate.edu/course/STEM-Innovation-Training-Lens-of-the-Market-Research2Innovation?hsLang=en
